title: Jeremy Renner says it's 'not his job' to help negotiate equal pay for female co-stars
text:
Jeremy Renner says it's 'not his job' to help negotiate equal pay for female co-stars Jeremy Renner says it's 'not his job' to help negotiate equal pay for female co-stars 
Press Association 2014 / / National Entertainment News Share 
Jeremy Renner has said it’s “not his job” to help his female co-stars close the wage gap – despite fellow American Hustle star Bradley Cooper throwing his support behind Jennifer Lawrence’s cause. 
J-Law recently penned an essay about the wage disparity in Hollywood, noting that she and Amy Adams were paid significantly less than their male co-stars in 2013′s American Hustle. The cast of American Hustle (Evan Agostini/AP) 
Bradley was taken aback, and told Reuters he would begin teaming up with female co-stars to negotiate fair salaries together before committing to a film. 
But Jeremy told Business Insider he wouldn’t be following Bradley’s lead. 
“That’s not my job,” he said. “I don’t know contracts and money and all that sort of stuff. 
“I’m a performer and I know human behaviour. When it comes to that sort of stuff I let other people deal with that. I do what I’m good at, that’s what I focus on.” Jeremy Renner (Michael Plunkett/AP) 
He added that he supports the idea of equal pay, but wants to focus on acting as a craft. 
Hollywood stars tend to leave deals to agents, managers and lawyers – but the much-publicised Sony hack surprised many by laying bare the wage disparity through leaked emails. Promoted stories 
Actresses including Jessica Chastain and Rooney Mara have since said they’ve been paid less than male co-stars, while Sienna Miller said she turned down a role in a play that was offering significantly less than was given to the male lead. Jeremy Renner and Jennifer Lawrence together in 2012 (Paul Bruinooge/AP) 
Jennifer was named by Forbes as 2015′s highest-paid actress in the world, earning 52 million dollars (£33.6 million) – but Robert Downey Jr was the highest-paid actor, with 80 million dollars (£51.7 million). 
She said in her essay that she learned how much Bradley, Jeremy and the other male actors made on American Hustle through the Sony leaks, and was annoyed at herself for not negotiating harder. 
She wrote: “But if I’m honest with myself, I would be lying if I didn’t say there was an element of wanting to be liked that influenced my decision to close the deal without a real fight. I didn’t want to seem ‘difficult’ or ‘spoiled’. 
“At the time, that seemed like a fine idea, until I saw the payroll on the internet and realised every man I was working with definitely didn’t worry about being ‘difficult’ or ‘spoiled’.” Jennifer Lawrence (Charles Sykes/Invision) 
Bradley has previously been in trouble for his remarks about women. Share article 
Earlier this year the 44-year-old actor faced criticism after he and his Avengers co-star Chris Evans referred to Scarlett Johansson’s character Black Widow as a “slut”. Promoted Stories
